questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the given picture.
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Components
  • Levator ani (pubococcygeus, puborectalis, iliococcygeus)
  • Coccygeus

Function
  • Supports pelvic organs
  • Aids in defecation, urination, and childbirth
  • Maintains continence

Openings
  • Urogenital hiatus (for urethra and vagina)
  • Anal hiatus (for rectum)

Clinical Relevance
  • Pelvic organ prolapse if weak
  • Urinary/fecal incontinence
  • Perineal tears in childbirth

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the levator ani muscles is incorrect?
questions.explanation:
Component

Function

Puborectalis muscle

Wraps around the rectum, forming a sling-like structure. It helps maintain continence by maintaining a kink in the rectum and assisting in closing the anus.

Pubococcygeus muscle

Forms the bulk of the levator ani muscles. It supports the pelvic organs (bladder, uterus, and rectum), helps control urine flow, contracts during orgasm, and plays a role in maintaining vaginal tone.

Iliococcygeus muscle

Forms the posterior part of the levator ani muscles. It supports the pelvic organs, aids in controlling urine flow, and helps maintain vaginal tone. It also provides stability to the pelvic floor.

Coccygeus muscle

Also known as the ischiococcygeus muscle, it is often considered a separate muscle but is functionally related to the levator ani. It provides support to the pelvic organs and aids in stabilizing the pelvic floor.

questions.text: Identify the foramen marked in the image below:-
questions.explanation:
Foramen of Middle Cranial Fossa

Structures Passing through

Foramen Rotundum

Maxillary Nerve

 

Foramen Ovale

  • Mandibular nerve

  • Accessory meningeal artery

  • Lesser petrosal nerve

  • Emissary vein

  • Occasionally, the Anterior trunk of the middle meningeal vein

Foramen Spinosum

  • Middle meningeal artery and vein,

  • Emissary vein

  • Nervus spinosus(Meningeal branch of mandibular nerve)

Foramen Lacerum

A triangular opening at the base of the skull, but in living individuals, it is filled with cartilage, and no major structures pass through it.

  • Foramen lacerum contributed by 3 bones-temporal, occipital and sphenoid

  • The internal carotid artery and nerve plexus traverse its superior end;

  • The nerve to the pterygoid canal passes through its anterior wall.

  • The meningeal branch of the ascending pharyngeal artery and an emissary vein pass through it.

questions.text: What is the action of the muscle at the hip, which is attached to the marked area in the image below?
The structures marked in the image below are found in the epithelial lining of all of the following sites, except:
During walking, the hip bone on the side of the suspended leg is raised by the action of which muscle present in the supporting leg?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Origin

Ilium (between anterior and posterior gluteal lines)

Insertion

Greater trochanter of femur

Innervation

Superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1)

Function

Hip abduction, pelvic stabilization during gait

Clinical Relevance

Weakness leads to Trendelenburg sign/gait, seen in superior gluteal nerve injury

Action

Muscles

Nerve supply


 

Flexion
  • Psoas major (chief flexor)

Anterior rami of L1, L2, L3
  • Iliacus (chief flexor)
  • Sartorius
  • Rectus femoris
  • Pectineus

Femoral nerve (L2, L3)
 

Extension
  • Gluteus maximus (chief extensor)

Inferior gluteal nerve (L5, S1, S2)
  • Hamstring muscles

Tibial part of the sciatic nerve (L5, S1, S2)
 

Abduction
  • Gluteus medius and minimus (chief abductors)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)


 

Adduction
  • Adductor longus
  • Adductor brevis
  • Adductor magnus (chief adductors)
  • Gracilis

Obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Pectineus

Double nerve supply (Femoral nerve and obturator nerve)
 

Medial rotation
  • Anterior fibres of gluteus minimus and medius (chief medial rotators)
  • Tensor fasciae latae

Superior gluteal nerve (L5, S1)





 

Lateral rotation
  • Piriformis

Ventral rami of S1, S2
  • Obturator externus

Posterior division of obturator nerve (L2, L3, L4)
  • Obturator internus and
  • Associated gemelli,
  • Quadratus femoris (These muscles are generally termed short rotators)

Nerve to obturator internus (L5, S1, S2)

questions.text: In the scenario of a man who fell into a manhole and sustained perineal injury, leading to difficulty in urination and presence of blood at the urethral tip, a diagnosis of bulbar urethral injury was determined. In this particular case, where would the urine accumulation be the least expected?
questions.correct_answer: C. The medial portion of thigh
questions.explanation:
Type of Urethral Injury

Common Cause

Urine Accumulation

Areas Restricted

Bulbar urethral injury (Spongy urethra rupture)

Straddle injury (e.g., falling on a hard object)

Perineum, scrotum, penis, anterior abdominal wall

Thigh (due to attachment of Colles' fascia)

Membranous urethral injury

Pelvic fractures

Retropubic space, perineum

Scrotum and penis (if Buck’s fascia remains intact)

Penile urethral injury

Blunt trauma or catheterization

Confined within Buck’s fascia if intact, or perineum if ruptured

None if Buck’s fascia is disrupted

questions.text: A woman delivered a healthy baby and to control her postpartum hemorrhage an artery was ligated. Then later she developed pain under her gluteus muscle. Which was the artery ligated ?
questions.explanation:
Artery

Origin

Major Branches

Supply

Clinical Significance

Internal Iliac Artery

Common iliac artery

Anterior and posterior divisions

Pelvic organs, gluteal region, perineum

Ligation used in PPH management

Uterine Artery

Anterior division of internal iliac

Anastomoses with ovarian artery

Uterus, cervix, vagina

Commonly ligated in hysterectomy

Superior Gluteal Artery

Posterior division of internal iliac

Branches to gluteal muscles

Gluteus medius, minimus, and tensor fascia lata

Injury can cause Trendelenburg gait

Inferior Gluteal Artery

Anterior division of internal iliac

Supplies deeper gluteal structures

Gluteus maximus, sciatic nerve

Injury affects hip extension

questions.text: The rupture of the penile urethra does not cause extravasation of blood into which of the following spaces?
questions.explanation:
Urethral injury causes

Anterior urethra

Meatus

Instrumentation, iatrogenic, hypospadias, skin disorders (lichen sclerosus)

Pendulous urethra

Instrumentation, iatrogenic, hypospadias, skin disorders (lichen sclerosus), sexually transmitted infections, crush injury

Bulbar urethra

Instrumentation, iatrogenic, skin disorders (lichen sclerosus), sexually transmitted infections, crush injury, straddle-type injury

Urethral injury causes

Posterior urethra

Membranous urethra

Instrumentation, pelvic fracture with urethral distraction defects

Prostatic urethra

Instrumentation, radiation therapy for prostate cancer (external beam radiation therapy, brachytherapy)

Bladder neck

questions.text: Which muscles are responsible for constituting the pelvic diaphragm? A. Iliococcygeus B. Pubococcygeus C. Obturator internus D. Deep transverse perinei
What is the volume of the prostate in healthy adult males?
questions.explanation:
Zone

Features

Peripheral
  • This zone makes up about 70% of the prostate gland and surrounds the urethra.
  • The majority of prostate cancers (70-80%) originate in the peripheral zone, since it is rich in glandular tissue, making it susceptible.

Central
  • It is situated at the base of the prostate gland, surrounding the ejaculatory ducts.
  • Inflammation of the prostate gland (prostatitis) commonly affects the central zone.

Transitional
  • It is located near the urethra and accounts for about 5-10% of the prostate gland.
  • BPH primarily affects the transitional zone, leading to urinary symptoms such as frequency, urgency, weak urine flow, and difficulty initiating or stopping urination.

questions.text: A person who had a road traffic accident presented to ER with injury to bulbar urethra. What can be the location of collection of the urine due to this injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Anal canal inferior to the pectinate line

questions.correct_answer: A. Anal canal inferior to the pectinate line

questions.text: What is the vertebral level shown by the blue line in the image?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B - L4-L5 

References:

  • ↳ If the blue line is at the L4-L5 level, then this option is correct. L4-L5 refers to the intervertebral space between the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) and the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). This is a common area for vertebral numbering and is often used as a reference point in medical and anatomical contexts.
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Incorrect Options:
  • ↳ Option A - L2-L3: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. The L2-L3 level would be higher up on the spine, and if the blue line is visibly at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.
  • ↳ Option A - L2-L3:
  • ↳ Option C - L5-S1: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L5-S1 refers to the intervertebral space between the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5) and the first sacral vertebra (S1), which is lower down the spine. If the blue line is at L4-L5, then this option is not the correct answer.
  • ↳ Option C - L5-S1:
  • ↳ Option D - L3-L4: This option is incorrect as the blue line is at the L4-L5 level. L3-L4 refers to the intervertebral space between the third lumbar vertebra (L3) and the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4). If the blue line is visible at the L4-L5 level, then this option is not the correct answer.
  • ↳ Option D - L3-L4:
    • References:

    • ↳ L4-L5 refers to the intervertebral space between the fourth lumbar vertebra (L4) and the fifth lumbar vertebra (L5). This is a common area for vertebral numbering and is often used as a reference point in medical and anatomical contexts.

questions.text: The ischial spine corresponds to which level?
questions.explanation:
Correct Option B -

References:

  • ↳ The ischial spine refers to the sharp bony prominence which protrudes from the posterior margin of the ischium. It separates the greater sciatic notch above from the lesser sciatic notch below.
  • ↳ Despite commonly being referenced in relation to the S3-S5 vertebral level in some anatomical texts, in certain contexts or specific anatomical references, it may be aligned or associated with the tip of the coccyx.
